abstract: <jats:p>Copy Number Variation (<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">CNV</jats:styled-content>) is increasingly implicated in disease pathogenesis. <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">CNV</jats:styled-content>s are often identified by statistical models applied to data from single nucleotide polymorphism panels. Family information for samples provides additional information for <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">CNV</jats:styled-content> inference. Two modes of Penn<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">CNV</jats:styled-content> (the <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">J</jats:styled-content>oint‐call and <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">P</jats:styled-content>osterior‐call), which are some of the most well‐developed family‐based <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">CNV</jats:styled-content> calling methods, use a “<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">J</jats:styled-content>oint‐model” as a main component. This models all family members’ <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">CNV</jats:styled-content> states together with <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">M</jats:styled-content>endelian inheritance. Methods based on the <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">J</jats:styled-content>oint‐model are used to infer <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">CNV</jats:styled-content> calls of cases and controls in a pedigree, which may be compared to each other to test an association. Although benefits from the <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">J</jats:styled-content>oint‐model have been shown elsewhere, equality of call rates in parents and offspring has not been evaluated previously. This can affect downstream analyses in studies that compare <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">CNV</jats:styled-content> rates in cases vs. controls in pedigrees. In this paper, we show that the <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">J</jats:styled-content>oint‐model can introduce different <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">CNV</jats:styled-content> call rates among family members in the absence of a true difference. We show that the <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">J</jats:styled-content>oint‐model may analytically introduce differential <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">CNV</jats:styled-content> calls because of asymmetry of the model. We demonstrate these differential call rates using single‐marker simulations. We show that call rates using the two modes of <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">P</jats:styled-content>enn<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">CNV</jats:styled-content> also differ between parents and offspring in one multimarker simulated dataset and two real datasets. Our results advise need for caution in use of the <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">J</jats:styled-content>oint‐model calls in <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">CNV</jats:styled-content> association studies with family‐based datasets. Genet. Epidemiol. 36:488‐498, 2012. © 2012 Wiley Periodicals, Inc.</jats:p>

title: Inheritance Model Introduces Differential Bias in <scp>CNV</scp> Calls Between Parents and Offspring
